Title: SEBI Tightens Social Media Ad Rules for Registered Intermediaries
URL: https://www.medianama.com/2025/03/223-sebi-tightens-social-media-ad-rules-for-registered-intermediaries/
Time Published: 2025-03-24T11:45:21Z
Full Content:
MEDIANAMA Technology and policy in India The Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) has directed registered intermediaries uploading advertisements on social media platforms to use email IDs and mobile numbers registered on the SEBI intermediary (SI) portal while signing up. In an advisory issued on March 21, the regulator also directed such intermediaries to update their contact details on the SI portal by April 30, 2025. Further, Social Media Platform Providers (SMPPs) like Google and Meta would later conduct advertiser verification of such entities. SEBI‚Äôs new guidelines come amid rising frauds in the securities market on social media platforms including YouTube, Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, X, Telegram, and app stores. The regulator noted the patterns like perpetrators luring victims in the guise of providing online trading courses and seminars, furnishing misleading testimonials, or guaranteeing risk-free returns on social media. Besides this, Ananth Narayan, SEBI‚Äôs whole-time member (WTM), also announced in a speech that the regulator, in collaboration with social media companies, has removed 70,000 misleading posts and handles since October 2024. However, this is not the first time SEBI has cautioned users and registered intermediaries of such activities on social media. In December 2024, the Board advised investors to not conduct transactions or share sensitive personal details on unauthorised or unregistered electronic platforms, noting that such platforms violate laws like the Securities Contract (Regulation) Act, 1956 and the SEBI Act, 1992. Previously, in August 2024, the Bombay and National Stock Exchanges furnished a joint report urging investors to refrain from joining social media forums like WhatsApp, Telegram, or Instagram channels providing stock recommendations or falsely offering trading opportunities through fake SEBI-issued certificates. The exchanges also highlighted other illegal online activities like offering ‚Äúdabba‚Äù or illegal trading services, claims to facilitate pre-IPO subscriptions with false promises of assured profits, impersonating applications of registered trading members, etc. The intermediaries clarified that victims of such fraud communications can report these through the Sanchar Saathi Portal, the National Cyber Crime Reporting Portal, or the 1930 cybercrime helpline number. Notably, in 2022 SEBI conducted raids in multiple cities across the country for operating Telegram channels which made recommendations of selected listed scrips, creating artificial volume and price rise. In 2024, SEBI also released a consultation paper highlighting when a platform is recognised as a ‚ÄòSpecified Digital Platform‚Äô (SDP), stipulating that these portals take measures like leveraging AI and ML to curb illegal activity on their platforms and prohibiting associations between unregistered influencers and registered intermediaries. Further, SDPs were directed to enable SEBI and its registered entities to escalate or report unlawful content alongside establishing a mechanism to report misleading content or advertisements. Debating the justification of this regulation, speakers at MediaNama‚Äôs discussion on ‚ÄúSEBI Platform and Influencer Regulations‚Äù disclosed that the law is all-encompassing and could even impact platforms like WhatsApp where users forward trading advice. Capital Mind Founder and CEO Deepak Shenoy also compared individuals offering free trading advice on platforms like YouTube to similar advice furnished on TV channels, with SEBI cracking down on the former and taking down videos from different creators and channels. Returning to the advisory, it also notes that SMPPs must conduct advertiser verification post the onboarding of such users. Google‚Äôs advertiser verification for financial services stipulates that entities must demonstrate that they are licensed by the relevant financial regulator‚ÄîSEBI in this case‚Äîand later obtain third-party verification from Google‚Äôs vendor G2. Notably, advertisers, such as search engines or e-commerce platforms, who don‚Äôt promote financial services but have a ‚Äúcompelling reason to target users‚Äù seeking financial advice must also apply to G2. And evidently, only authorised representatives can submit such applications. This requirement for authorisation by relevant regulatory authorities extends to Meta‚Äôs advertiser verification process for countries like Taiwan, Australia, and the UK. Also Read: Support our journalism: Sign up for our Daily Newsletter to receive regular updates Stay informed about MediaNama events Have something to tell us? Leave an Anonymous Tip Ask us to File an RTI Sponsor a MediaNama Event Jairam Ramesh complain is similar to RTI activists concern that Section 44(3) of DPDPA can turn ‚ÄúRight to Information‚Äù into ‚ÄúRight to Denial of Information,‚Äù as personal information would be denied. India is cracking down on illegal offshore online gaming platforms, imposing strict GST regulations and blocking websites. MediaNama is the premier source of information and analysis on Technology Policy in India. More about MediaNama, and contact information, here. ¬© 2024 Mixed Bag Media Pvt. Ltd.

Title: 11+ Real-World AI Agent Examples
URL: https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ai-agent-examples#article
Time Published: 2025-03-24T11:30:00Z
Full Content:

Each week, hosts Sam Parr and Shaan Puri explore new business ideas based on trends and opportunities in the market Redefining what success means and how you can find more joy, ease, and peace in the pursuit of your goals A daily dose of irreverent, offbeat, and informative takes on business and tech news Each week, Another Bite breaks down the latest and greatest pitches from Shark Tank Build your business for far and fast success HubSpot CMO Kipp Bodnar and Zapier CMO Kieran Flanagan share what's happening now in marketing and what's ahead Expand your knowledge and take control of your career with our in-depth guides, lessons, and tools. See pricing Sales CRM software. Free and premium plans Customer service software. Free and premium plans Content marketing software. Free and premium plans Operations software. Free and premium plans B2B commerce software. Free and premium plans Try another search, and we'll give it our best shot. New research into how marketers are using AI and key insights into the future of marketing with AI. Updated: 03/24/25 Published: 03/14/25 AI agents are like the backstage crew at the concerts we attend: Operating independently on the backend to deliver a smooth experience on the user end. They power many of the tech we use ‚Äì and have for a while ‚Äì but haven‚Äôt gotten that visibility until recently. In this article, we‚Äôll break down real-world examples of how AI agents are used across industries. Every time you sift through recommendations on your Netflix, you‚Äôre seeing AI agents at work. AI agents take action without constant human intervention by recognizing patterns and predicting behavior. When Netflix is recommending you shows to watch, that rec list has been compiled by an AI agent tasked with analyzing your watch history and ratings for trends and genre preferences. Brands like Amazon, YouTube, and Spotify all use similar agents to personalize user experience. New research into how marketers are using AI and key insights into the future of marketing. All fields are required. Click this link to access this resource at any time. Hotels, ride-hailing apps, and airlines all have one thing in common: Surge pricing ‚Äì powered by AI agents. These companies operate on a flexible pricing structure that fluctuates based on factors like supply, demand, and user trends. Source Take Lyft for instance. If I order a ride at 2 a.m. on a Saturday during Art Basel, it will surely cost me more than on a Tuesday night at 8 a.m. When the user even places the request for a ride, the AI agent evaluates these factors, sets the price, and responds to the user‚Äôs request. OpenAI and Google have both introduced AI agents, ‚Äì Operator and Mariner respectively ‚Äì that can search the web independently and serve as a true assistant, filling up shopping carts and getting answers to your most pressing questions. ‚ÄúIt can understand that it needs to press a button to make something happen,‚Äù Demis Hassabis, who oversees Google‚Äôs core A.I. lab, said in an interview with The NYT. ‚ÄúIt can take action in the world.‚Äù Source While AI assistants escalate support requests and direct users toward self-service options, AI agents are working behind the scenes to: Sites built on user-generated content ‚Äì think Reddit, YouTube, Meta ‚Äì require advanced content moderation practices to keep users safe. Human moderators rely on AI agents to do some of the legwork of flagging, reviewing, and sorting content that goes against the site‚Äôs policies. Think about how good YouTube has gotten at flagging when a video includes copyrighted music. There‚Äôs no human reviewing each upload ‚Äì instead, Google relies on AI systems to analyze content as they‚Äôre uploaded to the site and take actions if they‚Äôre not compliant. For instance, on YouTube, an uploaded video will be muted automatically if it includes copyrighted music. On TikTok, a content creator‚Äôs video will be first muted, then removed for review. These steps allow moderation teams to focus on higher priority work and automate routine tasks. When you‚Äôre spending money on an ad, you‚Äôre looking for return on investment (ROI). Doing so entails optimizing your ad after it‚Äôs placed ‚Äì that can mean anything from doubling down on the version that performs the best to customizing the ad based on user history. While this can be done manually, it‚Äôs not scalable ‚Äì and that‚Äôs where an AI agent comes in. Based on historical trends and performance data, advertisers can optimize their campaigns in real time, which saves them money and increases ROI. Recruiters on LinkedIn can now automate routine tasks like finding and following up with candidates, and scheduling interviews. Source According to LinkedIn, recruiters report spending around 20 hours a week on these tasks, and these AI agents can cut that time by half ‚Äì at least. While I haven‚Äôt had the chance to (read: the guts to) ride in a Waymo, Google‚Äôs robotaxi, I can tell you a bit about how it works. To operate safely, Waymo vehicles must rely on AI systems to perceive their surroundings, understand other drivers‚Äô behaviors, control the vehicle, and make safe driving decisions. It relies on real-time and historical data to guide and adapt its actions. Tesla‚Äôs AutoPilot feature is another example of an AI agent at work. The stock market is unpredictable. Imagine if you had an AI agent tracking it during pre- and open market hours to recommend strategies? Beyond recommendations, consumers and businesses alike are beginning to leverage AI agents to make trades based on their own risk profiles and investment strategies. U.S. hospitals and healthcare orgs, like Mayo Clinic, are piloting the use of AI agents for a series of administrative tasks, including: ‚ÄúFor some years now, we‚Äòve collected mountains of data in EHRs and data lakes but struggled to translate those insights into meaningful impact. Too often, it‚Äôs added more burden to clinicians instead of relieving it," said the executive director for Atlantic Health System, an org overseeing over 550 medical care sites, to Becker‚Äôs Health It. The next time you get a fraud alert notification from your bank, you‚Äôve likely got an AI agent to thank. (Or rather the team who configured it.) In the banking space, AI agents monitor users‚Äô transaction activity and track spending habits. When they flag behaviors that fall outside of routine, they‚Äôll respond by freezing cards, alerting users, and requesting transaction approvals. BMW is one of many companies using AI-powered robots to streamline production lines. They operate through a series of complex AI systems that assign them tasks and program them to adjust their behavior based on historical data. Alongside humans, production lines function much more smoothly, allowing workers to focus on higher-impact tasks that require human oversight. As you can now see, AI agents are working all around us. Title: Would You Buy a Fighter Jet From Donald Trump?
URL: http://nymag.com/intelligencer/article/trump-f-35-fighter-jet-allies.html
Time Published: 2025-03-24T09:00:43Z
Full Content:
Not so long ago, the F-35 fighter jet was the hottest ticket in the international arms market. Though it had suffered teething pains in development, going over budget by 50 percent in its first decade, Lockheed Martin‚Äôs Lightning II glowed up into a remarkably capable weapons platform. Stealthy, supersonic, and able to both dogfight and strike targets on the ground, it‚Äôs arguably the most sophisticated weapon in the U.S. arsenal and undeniably the most sought-after. As nation after nation held competitions to choose their next frontline fighter, the F-35 came in and trounced its rivals time and again. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt think of a competition that it entered in Europe that it didn‚Äôt win,‚Äù says Douglas Barrie, a senior fellow at the International Institute for Strategic Studies. ‚ÄúAnywhere Lockheed Martin pitched the F-35, it wound up getting chosen.‚Äù Today, some 18 years after its first flight, more than 1,000 F-35s are in operation in 20 countries. But then, earlier this month, something happened. One after another, nations that had signed up for the F-35 started voicing qualms. On March 13, Portugal‚Äôs defense minister said that the country would cancel plans to buy the plane. Then Canada‚Äôs prime minister said it would reconsider its purchase. Germany, too, is said to be wavering in its commitment to the jet. Nothing had changed about the plane‚Äôs performance. It‚Äôs just that, in the eyes of some international customers, the F-35 can‚Äôt fully be trusted anymore because of who is the commander-in-chief. Donald Trump has an affinity for authoritarianism, has exhibited poor treatment of NATO (whose Article 5 obligates collective defense), and, in particular, has threatened to annex Greenland and Canada. ‚ÄúCanada is one of our closest allies, and they have fought with us. They have died with us,‚Äù says Cynthia Cook, a senior fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. ‚ÄúAnd to have the new president of the United States cast doubt on their independence is really viewed as a challenging pill to swallow. It‚Äôs making the U.S. be seen as a less reliable ally.‚Äù The long-term effects of America‚Äôs heel turn might not just be deleterious for the F-35 program but for the $238 billion U.S. weapons-export industry as a whole, including the recently announced Boeing F-47 next-generation fighter, which could enter service in the 2030s. If the ‚Äúarsenal of democracy‚Äù no longer stands on the side of democracies, what is it good for? To understand why the F-35 is suddenly in trouble, the first thing you need to know is that a state-of-the-art fighter jet isn‚Äôt just a physical airframe. It‚Äôs both hardware and software, a whole suite of networked systems that requires software patches and data in order to work effectively. It‚Äôs a bit like a smartphone: If you don‚Äôt update the software, it gradually works less and less well and eventually bricks. The F-35 has to depend on software because of the environment it will fight in. Even though the plane is stealthy, meaning hard to detect by conventional radar, it is not invisible and will not survive long in a modern air-defense environment unless it can track and assess enemy radars and countermeasures. To do that, it needs to constantly update its assessment of the threat environment. That information is stored inside a software package called the mission data file, or MDF. The software is updated by a civilian unit located at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida called the F-35 Partner Support Complex, whose website explains that nations deploying the F-35 ‚Äúare not allowed to conduct independent test operations‚Äù outside the U.S. and that ‚ÄúU.S. citizens perform specific functions in order to protect critical U.S. technology.‚Äù In other words, any one nation that flies the F-35 is wholly dependent on the U.S. to keep the planes functioning properly. When the program launched, this provision rankled some allies, but it didn‚Äôt prove to be a deal-breaker because it was inconceivable at the time that the U.S. would ever be anything other than a trusted ally. (Israel, presciently, insisted on retaining control of the F-35‚Äôs software and today operates the aircraft with considerably more autonomy.) Buying planes that they don‚Äôt fully control now looks like an incredibly poor decision. Since Trump took office, Europe‚Äôs trust in its ally has withered as the U.S. has pivoted from democracy toward autocracy, increasingly aligned with Europe‚Äôs most dangerous adversary, Russia. As the legendary aviation journalist Bill Sweetman writes, ‚ÄúA hypothetical: A crisis is emerging, and U.S. strategy and policy differs from that of a partner nation; the U.S. is not going to intervene militarily at any likely threshold. The pressure point is simple: The door code at Eglin is changed. The partner nation‚Äôs people can‚Äôt get in.‚Äù Effectively, the F-35 is bricked. The delicacy of the situation that Europe now finds itself in goes far beyond the F-35 or any of the other major weapons systems that it is heavily dependent on the U.S. to maintain and operate, like the U.K.‚Äôs nuclear-weapons program. It‚Äôs that the whole defense edifice, from top to bottom, has been designed with a deep level of interdependence baked in. ‚ÄúOne of the strengths of the U.S. defense industrial cooperation is we‚Äôre able to incorporate the best offerings from our allies and partners from their technological advances,‚Äù Cook says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs something that our adversaries like Russia and China can envy but not replicate.‚Äù The idea that the U.S. would just walk away from a global security system that it has spent the better part of a century building and nurturing, and which undergirds the country‚Äôs global power, is nearly incomprehensible. For Europeans, it‚Äôs a bit like coming home and finding your husband in bed with the au pair. The swiftness and profundity of the betrayal is so enraging that a lifetime of commitment can vanish in an instant. ‚ÄúSince I‚Äôve been born, all I‚Äôve ever known was a U.S. alliance,‚Äù says Thomas Withington, a white-haired associate fellow at the Royal United Services Institute, Britain‚Äôs venerable defense think tank. ‚ÄúOccasionally, there‚Äôs been good-natured criticism on both sides of the Atlantic. But nobody has ever envisaged a world in which the U.S. and Europe are not very strong security partners. And what‚Äôs shocking to me now is that I have a number of friends ‚Äî mainly French but German and Italian as well ‚Äî who were quite strong Atlanticists but have totally changed their position in the last two weeks. ‚ÄúI was having a drink with a colleague last week, and he said that he remembered vividly how in the wake of 9/11, the U.S. declared Article 5 and pretty much all allied nations around the world stepped up. And he said, ‚ÄòGod forbid if that happens again, because we would never assist America in any future wars.‚Äô He was very adamant: Europe must not come to U.S. aid in the future. The U.S. is on its own.‚Äù ‚ÄúTrust is hard to win, and it‚Äôs really easy to lose,‚Äù Barrie says. ‚ÄúEven if this is a four-year blip in terms of the transatlantic relationship, it‚Äôs going to take a bit of time to move back toward a more balanced position.‚Äù For now, even if Trump‚Äôs most ominous pronouncements turn out to be mere bluster, Europe has been forced to confront how exposed it is. With remarkable speed, it has pivoted to the consensus that it needs to achieve self-reliance as quickly as it can, and that means replacing U.S. weapons and capabilities with those of a more dependable origin. With a friendly neighbor locked in an interminable and grinding bloodbath, the sense of urgency is real. As for the U.S., it is hard to see how it is going to come out ahead in this realignment. Trump often talks about rebuilding American manufacturing and restoring American military power around the world, but by torpedoing allies‚Äô trust in us, he has profoundly undermined the strategic capabilities of the U.S. military and tied an anchor around the defense industry, which last year reached a record-breaking $318 billion in overseas sales. ‚ÄúThe U.S. defense industry lives off exports,‚Äù says Withington. ‚ÄúAnd anything that that reduces that will have a serious effect ‚Äî and not only on the defense companies themselves but all of the businesses around them geographically. Think about all of the businesses that support the F-35 line in Fort Worth, everything from sandwich joints to real-estate agents and Uber drivers. There‚Äôs a whole ecosystem that‚Äôs developed. I saw what happened when the U.K.‚Äôs defense industry had to retool post‚ÄìCold War. Towns that were dependent on it just died.‚Äù If there‚Äôs a winner in all this, it‚Äôs Vladimir Putin. ‚ÄúIf you were to sit down with a blank sheet of paper and say, ‚ÄòWhat are the things, both in terms of domestic and international policy, that an American leader could do that would best suit Russia‚Äôs and China‚Äôs long-range strategic goals and visions?,‚Äô it looks a lot like the last 70 days,‚Äù says Steven Horrell, a senior fellow at the Center for European Policy Analysis. Another big beneficiary is European weapons-makers. Amid a planned surge in regional defense spending, French president Emmanuel Macron is pushing the Dassault Rafale as an alternative to the F-35, and Airbus is doing the same with the Eurofighter Typhoon. Sweden‚Äôs Saab, which makes the Gripen fighter jet, has seen its share price double since Trump took office, and German arms titan Rheinmetall has also doubled its stock value since last year. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre a European defense aerospace manufacturer,‚Äù says Barrie, ‚Äúsomebody else is doing your marketing work for you at the moment, and that‚Äôs the U.S.‚Äù By submitting your email, you agree to our Terms and Privacy Notice and to receive email correspondence from us.
